title: Chinese Embassy provides food and school supplies to Bujumbura Public Orphanage in December 2021
description: On December 16, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Burundi donated food, including rice and milk, and school supplies to the Bujumbura Public Orphanage Burundi. The embassy also helped to repair a damaged room of the orphanage. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A donation ceremony was held for this donation. Zhao Jiangping, the Chinese Ambassador in Burundi, and Ms. Sabhimik, the Minister of National Unity, Social Affairs, Human Rights and Gender Equality, attended the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese Embassy provides food and school supplies to Bujumbura Public Orphanage in December 2021

# Description
On December 16, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Burundi donated food, including rice and milk, and school supplies to the Bujumbura Public Orphanage Burundi. The embassy also helped to repair a damaged room of the orphanage. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A donation ceremony was held for this donation. Zhao Jiangping, the Chinese Ambassador in Burundi, and Ms. Sabhimik, the Minister of National Unity, Social Affairs, Human Rights and Gender Equality, attended the ceremony.
justification: Project focuses on humanitarian aid and social development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Food and school supplies donation to orphanage, facility repair, social development focus

title: Chinese Embassy in Burundi provides sporting goods to Burundi Disabled Persons' Federation in December 2021
description: On December 17, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Burundi made a material donation of daily necessities and sporting goods to the Burundi Disabled Persons' Federation. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.   There was a handover ceremony held for this donation. Chinese Ambassador in Burundi Zhao Jiangping, Chairman of the Burundi Disabled Persons Federation Bizabi Gomba, and Chairman of the Burundi Paralympic Committee Ensaba Yezu attended the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Embassy in Burundi provides sporting goods to Burundi Disabled Persons' Federation in December 2021

# Description
On December 17, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Burundi made a material donation of daily necessities and sporting goods to the Burundi Disabled Persons' Federation. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.   There was a handover ceremony held for this donation. Chinese Ambassador in Burundi Zhao Jiangping, Chairman of the Burundi Disabled Persons Federation Bizabi Gomba, and Chairman of the Burundi Paralympic Committee Ensaba Yezu attended the ceremony.
justification: Project involves donation of sporting goods and daily necessities to support disabled persons, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Material donation to Burundi Disabled Persons' Federation, focus on social support and development

title: Chinese Government donates 50,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $900,000 in June 2021
description: On June 12, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 50,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines and over 50,000 syringes to the Government of Cape Verde. During the handover ceremony for the vaccines at Nelson Mandela International Airport in the capital city of Praia, Cape Verdean Prime Minister Ulisses Correia e Silva expressed gratitude for China's support, saying his country would fulfill its vaccination plan to vaccinate 70 percent of the population by the end of this year.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the June 2021 donation as $900,000.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 50,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $900,000 in June 2021

# Description
On June 12, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 50,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines and over 50,000 syringes to the Government of Cape Verde. During the handover ceremony for the vaccines at Nelson Mandela International Airport in the capital city of Praia, Cape Verdean Prime Minister Ulisses Correia e Silva expressed gratitude for China's support, saying his country would fulfill its vaccination plan to vaccinate 70 percent of the population by the end of this year.
justification: Project is a healthcare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 50,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses and syringes, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government agrees to provide USD 1.5 million in technical assistance to Government of Cabo Verde in February 2021
description: On February 4, 2021, the Chinese Government signed an agreement with the Cabo Verde Ministry of Agriculture and the Environment and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations to provide USD 1.5 million in technical assistance to the Government of Cabo Verde. The technical assistance will help Cabo Verde with food security improvements including seaweed farming, and guidance to 4,500 farmers and 100 researchers.
staff_comments: 1. Sources indicate that the technical assistance is part of the South-South Cooperation Programme undertaken by China and the UN Food and Agriculture Organization
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government agrees to provide USD 1.5 million in technical assistance to Government of Cabo Verde in February 2021

# Description
On February 4, 2021, the Chinese Government signed an agreement with the Cabo Verde Ministry of Agriculture and the Environment and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations to provide USD 1.5 million in technical assistance to the Government of Cabo Verde. The technical assistance will help Cabo Verde with food security improvements including seaweed farming, and guidance to 4,500 farmers and 100 researchers.
justification: Project focuses on technical assistance for food security and agricultural development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Technical assistance for food security improvements, seaweed farming, and guidance to farmers and researchers

title: China commits to funding maternity and pediatric building at Cabo Verde’s Baptista de Sousa Hospital in January 2021
description: On January 28, 2021, the Chinese ambassador to Cabo Verde, Du Xiaocong, exchanged letters with the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Cabo Verde, Rui Figueiredo Soares, for the Chinese funding of a new maternity and pediatric building at Cabo Verde’s Baptista de Sousa Hospital.   On the same day, Du Xiacong and Rui Figueiredo Soares signed an inter-governmental economic and technical cooperation agreement (ETCA). The agreement will go toward projects within the São Vicente Marine Special Economic Zone (captured in Project ID #93126). The exchange of letters and ETCA are worth a combined RMB 100 million; the financial breakdown between projects is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title

On the same day, Du Xiacong and Rui Figueiredo Soares signed an inter-governmental economic and technical cooperation agreement (ETCA). The agreement will go toward projects within the São Vicente Marine Special Economic Zone (captured in Project ID #93126). The exchange of letters and ETCA are worth a combined RMB 100 million; the financial breakdown between projects is unknown.

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Cape Verde in 2021
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Cape Verde signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $2,710,000 ($2,062,000 in principal payments and $647,000 in interest payments).   However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.    Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Cape Verde. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0.2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Cape Verde secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Cape Verde in 2021

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Cape Verde signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $2,710,000 ($2,062,000 in principal payments and $647,000 in interest payments).   However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.    Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt suspension agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt service suspension agreement, no specific project or environmental component mentioned

title: CDB, Eximbank, ICBC, Bank of China, China Construction Bank provide $660 million syndicated loan for Siem Reap Angkor International Airport Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#66058)
description: On September 19, 2016, a special purpose vehicle called Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd. [吴哥国际机场投资（柬埔寨）有限公司] — that is jointly owned by Yunnan Investment Group, Yunnan Overseas Investment, and Yunnan Airport Group Co., Ltd. — was officially registered. Then, in 2021, a group of Chinese state-owned banks provided a $660 million syndicated loan to Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd. for the Siem Reap Angkor International Airport Project. The lenders were China Development Bank (as the Arranger, the Agent, and the Leading Bank); Yunnan Branch of Export-Import Bank of China (as the Joint Lead Bank); China Construction Bank (as a Participant Bank); Phnom Penh Branch of Bank of China (as a Participant Bank); and Phnom Penh Branch of Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (as a Participant Bank). China Development Bank Yunnan Branch conducted multi-party communications with the Cambodian Government, enterprises, and financial institutions, and took the lead in setting up a $660 million syndicated loan to support the construction of the airport. The maturity length of the loan is 20 years. The total project cost is $880 million and it is being financed according to a debt-to-equity ratio of 75:25. Yunnan Investment Group made a $220 million equity investment in this project (see Project ID#66058).   The purpose of the project is to construct a Level-4E airport in the Teuk Laak commune within the Toul Kork district, including an airstrip, 50,000 square meters terminal building, and supporting facilities like a 24.5 km airport road. Siem Reap Angkor International Airport is 40 km away from Angkor Wat and 51 km away from Siem Reap urban area, and the airport project covers an area of 700 hectares and another 1000 hectares of comprehensive development land. Upon completion, the new airport is expected to be able to handle 7 million passengers annually. The existing Angkor International Airport in Siem Reap is only 5 kilometers away from Angkor Wat (a Buddhist temple and the largest religious monument in the world) and has only one runway. As the existing airport is too close to Angkor Wat, the vibration generated by the take-off and landing of aircraft could damage the foundation of the Buddhist temple, and the airport’s throughput capacity cannot meet the rapid development of tourism.   The Siem Reap Angkor International Airport Construction Project is being implemented on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis. Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd. was granted a 55-year concession to construct and operate the airport and it will be handed over to the Cambodian Government after the end of this period. Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd., in turn, hired Shanxi Mechanization Construction Group to assist with project implementation activities. Construction began on March 15, 2020. However, project implementation was halted for an unidentified reason in 2020 (most likely the Covid-19 pandemic). However, in a meeting with H.E. Mao Havannall, Minister in charge of State Secretariat of Civil Aviation (SSCA) in Phnom Penh on May 11, 2020, Mr. Lu Wei, Chairman of Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd., said that the on-site work had resumed. Then, a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on the construction of the Angkor International Airport Project was signed June 4, 2020. By May 2021, the project had achieved a 42% completion rate. An initial loan disbursement of $60 million was also released in 2021. The Siem Reap Angkor International Airport Construction Project was originally scheduled for completion on March 14, 2023.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Angkor International Airport Construction Project. The Chinese project title is 柬埔寨暹粒吴哥国际机场 or 吴哥国际机场项目介绍 or 就吴哥国际机场项目 or 持了柬埔寨暹粒机场.2. In the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020, it identifies an $880 million loan from CDB and China Eximbank to the Government of Cambodia for this project. However, a detailed project description from ICBC notes that this project is being financed with a $660 million syndicated loan from CDB, Eximbank, ICBC, Bank of China, and China Construction Bank and the borrower is Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd. (not the Government of Cambodia).
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
CDB, Eximbank, ICBC, Bank of China, China Construction Bank provide $660 million syndicated loan for Siem Reap Angkor International Airport Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#66058)

# Description
On September 19, 2016, a special purpose vehicle called Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd. [吴哥国际机场投资（柬埔寨）有限公司] — that is jointly owned by Yunnan Investment Group, Yunnan Overseas Investment, and Yunnan Airport Group Co., Ltd. — was officially registered. Then, in 2021, a group of Chinese state-owned banks provided a $660 million syndicated loan to Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd. for the Siem Reap Angkor International Airport Project. The lenders were China Development Bank (as the Arranger, the Agent, and the Leading Bank); Yunnan Branch of Export-Import Bank of China (as the Joint Lead Bank); China Construction Bank (as a Participant Bank); Phnom Penh Branch of Bank of China (as a Participant Bank); and Phnom Penh Branch of Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (as a Participant Bank). China Development Bank Yunnan Branch conducted multi-party communications with the Cambodian Government, enterprises, and financial institutions, and took the lead in setting up a $660 million syndicated loan to support the construction of the airport. The maturity length of the loan is 20 years. The total project cost is $880 million and it is being financed according to a debt-to-equity ratio of 75:25. Yunnan Investment Group made a $220 million equity investment in this project (see Project ID#66058).   The purpose of the project is to construct a Level-4E airport in the Teuk Laak commune within the Toul Kork district, including an airstrip, 50,000 square meters terminal building, and supporting facilities like a 24.5 km airport road. Siem Reap Angkor International Airport is 40 km away from Angkor Wat and 51 km away from Siem Reap urban area, and the airport project covers an area of 700 hectares and another 1000 hectares of comprehensive development land. Upon completion, the new airport is expected to be able to handle 7 million passengers annually. The existing Angkor International Airport in Siem Reap is only 5 kilometers away from Angkor Wat (a Buddhist temple and the largest religious monument in the world) and has only one runway. As the existing airport is too close to Angkor Wat, the vibration generated by the take-off and landing of aircraft could damage the foundation of the Buddhist temple, and the airport’s throughput capacity cannot meet the rapid development of tourism.   The Siem Reap Angkor International Airport Construction Project is being implemented on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis. Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd. was granted a 55-year concession to construct and operate the airport and it will be handed over to the Cambodian Government after the end of this period. Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd., in turn, hired Shanxi Mechanization Construction Group to assist with project implementation activities. Construction began on March 15, 2020. However, project implementation was halted for an unidentified reason in 2020 (most likely the Covid-19 pandemic). However, in a meeting with H.E. Mao Havannall, Minister in charge of State Secretariat of Civil Aviation (SSCA) in Phnom Penh on May 11, 2020, Mr. Lu Wei, Chairman of Angkor International Airport Investment (Cambodia) Co., Ltd., said that the on-site work had resumed. Then, a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on the construction of the Angkor International Airport Project was signed June 4, 2020. By May 2021, the project had achieved a 42% completion rate. An initial loan disbursement of $60 million was also released in 2021. The Siem Reap Angkor International Airport Construction Project was originally scheduled for completion on March 14, 2023.
justification: Airport construction project with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of Level-4E airport with terminal building, airstrip, and supporting facilities; no mention of renewable energy or energy efficiency components
